definitions.definition: a flat paper container used for sending letters in, with a part that you stick down to close it

examples.text: Writing paper and envelopes are provided in your room.
He gave her the envelope of certificates.
She quickly stuffed the money back into the envelope.
I couldn't read the address on the envelope.
He had put the letter in the wrong envelope.
She scribbled his phone number on the back of an envelope.
Please enclose a self-addressed envelope if you would like a reply.
The letter was suspicious, and I considered steaming open the envelope.
To apply, use the enclosed reply-paid envelope (no stamp needed).
You don't earn much stuffing envelopes.
an envelope addressed in my mother's round handwriting

definitions.definition: a flat container made of plastic for keeping papers in

examples.text: Each item was tagged and sealed in a plastic envelope.

definitions.definition: used to talk about planning or calculating something in a way that is not detailed, exact or complete

examples.text: We added up our savings on the back of an envelope.

definitions.definition: to go beyond the limits of what is allowed or thought to be possible

examples.text: He is a performer who consistently pushes the envelope of TV comedy.

wordOrigin: mid 16th cent. (in the sense ‘wrapper, enveloping layer’; originally as envelope): from French enveloppe, from envelopper ‘envelop’. The sense ‘covering of a letter’ dates from the early 18th cent.
